conclusion: To find the potential difference \( U_{ab} \), calculate the induced emf in the rod due to its motion in the magnetic field.
The conductor rod \( ab \) of length \( 4L \) rotates with angular velocity \( \omega \).
Assume \( a \) is at the axis since the distance from point \( a \) to the axis \( O \) is negligible.
Linear velocity \( v \) is given by \( v = \omega \cdot r \), where \( r \) is the distance from the axis of rotation.
Different parts of the rod have different linear velocities; integrate over the length to find total induced emf.
Consider an infinitesimal element \( dr \) at distance \( r \) with velocity \( v = \omega r \).
The emf induced in an infinitesimal length \( dr \) is \( d\mathcal{E} = B \cdot (\omega r) \cdot dr = B\omega r \, dr \).
Integrate \( d\mathcal{E} \) from \( r = 0 \) to \( r = 4L \) to find total emf.
The potential difference \( U_{ab} \) is equivalent to the induced emf \( \mathcal{E} \).
The potential difference \( U_{ab} \) between end \( a \) and end \( b \) is \( U_{ab} = 8B\omega L^2 \).
